stories.headline: Wife and police chief testify
stories.summary: In a Morgan County courtroom, the wife of a chiropractor accused of poisoning in 2022 testified about their marriage and the events leading to the attempted murder charge against Brian Mann. Testimonies revealed hospital diagnosis of lead poisoning and insurance claims tied to Mann's wife. The trial's first day of witness testimony included key figures linked to Mann’s chiropractic office and State Farm insurance.

stories.headline: New deputy chief to start next week
stories.summary: Decatur Police Chief Torry Mack will bring in a new deputy chief, Eric Stisher, following approval from the Decatur City Council. The Personnel Board recommended Stisher for the role, with waived recruitment and interview process due to his exempt status. Stisher, formerly with the Birmingham Police Department, will undergo background checks before official start. The new deputy chief will help lead departmental review and support the chief’s initiatives.

stories.headline: Farmers contend with excessive rain
stories.summary: Farmers in west Limestone County face challenges due to excessive rain throughout the year, impacting their ability to plant and grow crops properly. National Weather Service reports above-normal rainfall this year, causing oversaturation in fields and problematic crop conditions. Farmers are adapting by replanting and managing the wet conditions to mitigate the effects on their yield.

stories.headline: Canyon County celebrates 2nd Pride festival, triples in size
stories.summary: The 2nd annual Canyon County Pride festival was a major success, tripling in size compared to the previous year. Held at Lakeview Park in Nampa, the event featured around 40 to 100 booths and thousands of attendees enjoying eight hours of festivities, including a concert by Joshua Emara. Organizers expressed pride in the substantial growth and community support for LGBTQ+ celebration in the area, making it a notable cultural event for Canyon County.

stories.headline: Child care crisis deepens as state takes over licensing
stories.summary: Boise is facing a growing child care crisis as the state will take over child care licensing starting July 1, ending many local incentive programs. City leaders had expanded child care access through incentives and better standards to support working parents, but state intervention will impose stricter regulations and lead to cuts in local programs including property tax rebates for in-home providers. The Idaho Department of Health and Welfare's move has disappointed local officials who fear it will worsen provider shortages and reduce quality of care access.

stories.headline: Idaho family reunited after wrongful detention in Cameroon
stories.summary: A woman from Idaho and her husband were reunited after being wrongfully detained in Cameroon due to a soured rental agreement and accusations of cyber defamation. The situation escalated to the involvement of the U.S. Senate, with Idaho's senior senator advocating for their release. The woman, Amber Murrey-Ndewa, is a criminal charges advocate and geography professor with ties to Cambridge High and College of Idaho. The case highlights international diplomatic tensions and wrongful law enforcement actions abroad.

stories.headline: 700 Marines deployed to LA after night of scattered protests
stories.summary: Hundreds of Marines were deployed to Los Angeles on Tuesday to reinforce federal law enforcement and National Guard troops amid protests against the Trump administration's immigration crackdown. The protests, including a significant rally on Monday afternoon, have seen confrontations between protesters and authorities. The Trump administration has doubled the deployment of National Guard troops in the area, with over 4,000 troops present in Los Angeles at one point. Despite increased arrests and police actions, clashes have been fewer overall compared to earlier in the week.

stories.headline: Hegseth grilled on deployment of troops to LA
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth faced sharp questions from lawmakers regarding his plan to deploy troops to Los Angeles. Bipartisan frustration was evident as Congress had not authorized full defense budget requests to support such actions. Critics, including rankings members of key committees, cited costs and potential overreach. Hegseth defended Trump's previous troop deployment decision as necessary to protect federal agents, warning that troop use inside the United States will continue to expand under the current administration.

stories.headline: Two US House committees consider new rules for digital assets
stories.summary: Two U.S. House committees are considering legislation to establish clearer regulatory frameworks for digital assets such as cryptocurrencies and stablecoins. The Financial Services and Agriculture committees held separate hearings to clarify the roles of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission in digital asset markets. Proposed bill amendments and discussions aim to facilitate comprehensive government oversight and consumer protections.

stories.headline: Austrians mourn shooting victims
stories.summary: Flowers and candles were placed at the entrance of a school in Graz, Austria, to honor the victims of a deadly shooting that recently took place there. The community gathered to grieve and pay respect to those affected by the tragedy.

stories.headline: US approves state’s SNAP limit request
stories.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture granted Arkansas a waiver requested by Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders allowing the state to cap the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits for confectionery products, artificially sweetened candy, and some other low-nutrition foods. Effective July 1, 2026, the waiver will eliminate eligibility for these items under SNAP to promote healthier food choices and combat chronic diseases. This measure aligns with broader federal efforts under the Make America Healthy Again initiative.

stories.headline: LA mayor declares curfew, cites vandalism and looting
stories.summary: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass declared a curfew from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m. in a designated downtown area to curb vandalism and looting. The curfew was enacted after protests escalated into violence and property damage across roughly 500 city blocks, following earlier federal budget tensions and immigration policy protests. The city aims to maintain safety and prevent further unrest amid ongoing tensions around law enforcement and immigration issues.

stories.headline: Patterson to leave role as UAMS chancellor
stories.summary: Dr. Cam Patterson announced he will step down as chancellor of the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences after seven years. His tenure focused heavily on patient care and medical advancements, and he expressed excitement about returning to academic and clinical missions full time. Patterson has served as chancellor since 2018 and was previously senior vice president and chief operating officer of New York-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center and Komansky Children's Hospital in New York City. He was recognized as a physician leader by Becker's Hospital Review.

stories.headline: Stinging and 'wicked' needle ants spreading across the U.S.
stories.summary: An invasive species of stinging carnivorous ants known as 'Asian needle ants' have been spreading slowly across 20 U.S. states, causing life-threatening anaphylactic reactions. The ants will reach peak numbers in summer but are difficult to detect due to their small size and tendency to sting silently. Experts warn about potential challenges and health risks associated with this growing problem.

stories.headline: George Takei gets candid about coming out
stories.summary: Actor and activist George Takei shares insights from his new memoir 'It Rhymes With Takei,' discussing his feelings of liberation and concerns about the state of democracy. He opens up about his personal journey and the importance of authenticity in his life and work.

stories.headline: Gambling addiction ringing alarm bells
stories.summary: Sam DeMello, once a successful marathoner with a six-figure salary, struggled silently with sports betting addiction. His addiction became apparent after friends and family noticed change following the 2013 San Francisco marathon. DeMello describes the ease of hiding the addiction and the dissonance he felt due to the façade of success and support around him.

stories.headline: Unmatched ubiquity: Shaq gets more rich and famous
stories.summary: Retired NBA icon Shaquille O'Neal continues to expand his influence and wealth through TV ads and licensing deals, maintaining prominence off the court. His broad presence in sports and marketing showcases his unmatched ubiquity and long-term career success.

stories.headline: Ex-Ford hauler builds new trucking startup
stories.summary: A former Ford truck hauler is cofounder of Squirrelly, a startup company in the trucking industry. The founder discusses the challenges faced and the personal satisfaction derived from launching a new business venture, highlighting entrepreneurial spirit in a competitive market.

stories.headline: Trump's military parade a statement
stories.summary: Donald Trump loves a parade, and his determination to stage a procession of America's troops and military hardware in Washington, D.C. reflects his vision of his role and the nation's leadership. The parade features 28 Abrams tanks, 50 military helicopters, and gold decor in the Oval Office, symbolizing power, wealth, and royalty. While some see it as inspiring, others call it alarming given the sweeping powers asserted.

stories.headline: Angelenos live in dread over what's next
stories.summary: Following a day of downtown protests and a federal immigration crackdown in Los Angeles, residents face chaotic scenes with heavy police presence and vandalism. Black and white police squad cars from surrounding cities line the streets, with graffiti and spray-painted messages on buildings. The community is concerned over escalating violence and uncertain future amid ongoing tensions.

stories.headline: General Mills buys Gladstone-based taco shell brand La Tiara
stories.summary: General Mills has acquired La Tiara, a Gladstone-based taco shell brand previously owned by Gladstone Food Products. The sale was approved by a Clay County Circuit Court judge although the buyer was not publicly disclosed at the time. The $10 million purchase expands General Mills' portfolio which includes other household brands such as Betty Crocker and Häagen-Dazs. The acquisition preserves La Tiara's legacy after it disappeared from store shelves earlier this year.

stories.headline: Court records unsealed in high-stakes Kansas abortion case
stories.summary: A cache of court records was unsealed in a major legal battle over abortion rights in Kansas between providers and Attorney General Kris Kobach. The declassified documents include patient complaints against Planned Parenthood and reveal new requirements that patients must complete before terminating pregnancies. The case could reshape access to reproductive healthcare statewide, with ongoing jury trials and disputes over abortion restrictions and provider requirements.
people: District Court Judge K. Christopher Jayaram

stories.headline: 700 Marines deployed to LA after night of scattered protests
stories.summary: In response to protests against the Trump administration's immigration crackdown, 700 Marines were deployed to Los Angeles to help protect federal law enforcement officers and property. The protests, which took place in downtown LA and involved demands on immigration issues, led to an extraordinary confrontation prompting the use of military personnel. The deployment is described as rare and reserved for extreme situations.

stories.headline: KC police department has ongoing issues with 911 calls
stories.summary: A woman in Kansas City encountered problems with 911 calls during an emergency involving a van and a possible abduction. The Kansas City police department faced ongoing challenges handling the situation, as it took time for first responders to act while the woman was in distress and able to provide details to the dispatcher. The incident highlights ongoing issues with emergency service responses.

stories.headline: Trump’s new fighter jet idea faces reality check
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s proposal for a new fighter jet faces skepticism and practical challenges, highlighting the complexity of military procurement and defense budgeting. The idea, which made headlines, is now encountering a reality check amid expert analysis and political considerations regarding feasibility and cost-effectiveness.

stories.headline: Infighting fuels concern about GOP megabill
stories.summary: Internal Republican conflicts and criticism from Elon Musk have heightened concerns about the future of President Donald Trump's major legislative package, known as the GOP megabill. The bill combines priorities such as tax cuts and border security. While some Senate Republicans oppose parts of the bill, including Medicaid cuts, GOP leaders are eager to pass it. Trump has publicly criticized Republicans in Congress to push for swift approval, emphasizing the need for bold changes before his deadline to sign the legislation.

stories.headline: NY bid to legalize lethal pills for terminally ill may rest with Hochul
stories.summary: New York is considering a move to legalize physician-assisted dying for terminally ill patients expected to die within six months. The bill has passed the Assembly and is pending in the Senate, with Governor Kathy Hochul's approval seen as crucial for its passage. Senate Majority Leader Andrea Stewart-Cousins indicated there are votes to pass the bill, but the final decision awaits the Senate Health Committee’s scheduling and Hochul’s stance.

stories.headline: House bill could change SNAP food program
stories.summary: A new House bill proposes significant changes to the SNAP food program, potentially requiring New Yorkers to prove they are working to continue receiving benefits. The bill, passed by House Republicans, could shift $290 billion in costs over ten years to New York and mandates new work requirements for beneficiaries, including adults under 55 who aren't disabled and must work at least 20 hours weekly. The changes are part of a broader legislative package that also includes tax cuts and other policy priorities under President Donald Trump’s agenda.

stories.headline: Democrats drop opposition to hearing on red flag vote
stories.summary: Democrats have dropped opposition to holding a hearing on a citizens initiative regarding a red flag vote scheduled for 3 p.m. Wednesday. The referendum proposal seeks to allow Maine voters to enact an extreme risk protection order law commonly called a “red flag” law. The law is intended to permit temporarily removing access to firearms from individuals deemed a danger to themselves or others. This comes amid continued pressure and legal threats from Republicans and gun rights groups.

stories.headline: Collins grills NIH director about slashed research funds
stories.summary: Senator Susan Collins questioned Dr. Jay Bhattacharya, the new director of the National Institutes of Health, as well as other senators, regarding the proposed 40% reduction in the NIH's 2026 budget. The proposed cuts have raised concerns about undoing years of congressional investment and damaging biomedical research. The Senate Appropriations Committee held a hearing on the matter, addressing the impacts on health and human services and education funding under the Trump administration's budget proposals.

stories.headline: Turnout light as Mainers decide school budgets, local races
stories.summary: Voter turnout was unusually light at polling places in Maine, including Cape Elizabeth, Gorham, and Scarborough, during voting on a $57.5 million school spending plan. Despite expectations that heated debates over spending proposals might increase turnout, only light crowds of voters showed up. Polling places saw small numbers of voters, and officials waited for the next voter to come in. The vote includes provision for same-day voter registration in some communities. Officials noted that the slow start could affect total participation.

stories.headline: Lewiston mother sues over son’s 2023 death in jail
stories.summary: Pamela Ashby is suing the Androscoggin County Jail and its health care provider Correctional Psychiatric Solutions after the death of her 25-year-old son Trevor Saunders from pneumonia at the jail. Ashby alleges the jail and its medical staff ignored her son's pain and cries for help, leading to his worsening condition and death in 2023. She claims the jail routinely dismisses and ignores inmates' medical complaints, reflecting a systemic problem with inadequate medical care and lack of constitutional protections at the facility.

stories.headline: Polls: President must obey Supreme Court
stories.summary: A new federal court ruling asserts that President Donald Trump must obey the Supreme Court, countering claims by some that presidents have unchecked powers. Polls show that a majority of Americans overwhelmingly recognize the judiciary's role in determining the legality of presidential actions. This includes questions of controlling executive and judicial branches and the president's obligation to follow court rulings. The public generally supports court authority, including issues like immigration and temporary judicial orders blocking some executive actions.

stories.headline: South side arrest sparks worries of widespread ICE actions
stories.summary: Federal agents arrested an immigrant on Milwaukee's south side, raising fears among residents and local officials of a broader immigration crackdown in the area. The arrest of an individual and their brother-in-law led to gatherings of federal agents in a heavily Latino neighborhood. Advocates expressed concerns over the potential spread of these immigration enforcement efforts, especially with actions ordered by President Donald Trump and National Guard involvement. Authorities have remained cautious in discussing operational details amid protests and community unease.

stories.headline: Foster dogs euthanized; rescue lied for months
stories.summary: Two puppies rescued from a hoarding situation in Texas and taken by a Milwaukee-based dog rescue were euthanized, though their foster parents believed they were adapting and placed in a sanctuary later. It was revealed through an investigation that the rescue group Misfit Mutt Crue KE took steps to hide these euthanasias, sparking concerns about rescue group accountability and regulation. Advocates point to the lack of regulation as a cause for recurring issues in rescue operations, with many animals pushed into less equipped rescues instead of proper sanctuaries.

stories.headline: MI schools face plague of incidents with guns
stories.summary: Michigan schools are grappling with a surge in gun-related incidents, involving children aged 3 to 18 who are bringing guns to school. Safety measures including metal detectors, bag checks, lockdown drills, and social media monitoring are being implemented to counter the problem. Incidents range from gun confiscations to injuries, including tragic events like the 2021 Oxford High School shooting that resulted in deaths and lifelong trauma for many. Law enforcement officials in multiple districts have increased efforts to control gun access on school grounds amid the ongoing crisis.

stories.headline: CA Gov. Newsom files for restraining order
stories.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom has filed for a temporary restraining order against President Donald Trump and Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth. This move follows the deployment of 700 Marines and Customs Enforcement to Los Angeles to control immigration protests, a step that Newsom and others see as an escalation that threatens American democracy. The federal government is accused of turning military force against American citizens, raising tensions in the city after National Guard troops were called in and protest clashes led to over 40 arrests.

stories.headline: Tourism season is a ‘mixed bag'
stories.summary: Alaska tourism operators report a season of mixed results, with some signs of slowdown due to economic concerns and the impact of Trump administration policies on trade and immigration. Despite strong growth in previous years, some cruise ships bookings are slower and international travelers have canceled trips. Operators remain cautiously optimistic but note challenges ahead.

stories.headline: LA leaders impose curfew as federal crackdown on immigration escalates
stories.summary: Los Angeles officials enacted a curfew following protests against President Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown and National Guard deployment. Governor Gavin Newsom sought legal intervention to stop federal immigration efforts that have intensified arrests and raised tensions nationwide. The curfew aims to reduce public disorder amid growing clashes over immigration enforcement in the city.

stories.headline: After weeks of gloomy conditions, sun will shine on Anchorage, Mat-Su
stories.summary: Following a record low temperature on June 10, Anchorage and Mat-Su residents can expect improving weather with rising temperatures and clearer skies. Despite recent weeks of clouds, rain, and snowy conditions atypical for June, weather forecasts signal a more favorable outlook moving forward this season.

stories.headline: ICE detainees expected to be in Alaska for about a month
stories.summary: Anchorage’s Cook Inlet Pretrial Facility is currently holding nearly 40 federal immigration detainees transferred from outside Alaska. These detainees are expected to remain in Alaska for about a month under a longstanding agreement between state officials and the federal government. Concerns remain about the detainees' origins and transfers following increased immigration arrests and deportations since early 2025.

stories.headline: Fayette school board pauses controversial tax increase
stories.summary: Facing pressure amid a state audit threat, Fayette school board chair Tyler Murphy and the board have decided to 'pause' plans to raise the occupational license tax for schools. The board canceled a public hearing and vote scheduled for June 23, following concerns from community members and a legal ruling that the school board failed to provide proper notice before requesting the fiscal court's involvement. The controversy sparked criticism from lawmakers and the Kentucky attorney general's office.

stories.headline: Developers, preservationists at odds over home near UK
stories.summary: A conflict is unfolding over a six-story apartment complex near the University of Kentucky, where a lawyer for the developer claims a demolition permit was mistakenly issued for a home that preservationists and neighbors want saved. The home at 245 Stone Ave. may be demolished to make way for a new fraternity house despite ongoing concerns and objections from the Blue Grass Trust and Stavroff Developers, who are involved in the project on East Maxwell Street.

stories.headline: Herald-Leader sports columnist John Clay is retiring
stories.summary: John Clay, a prominent sports columnist for the Lexington Herald-Leader, is retiring effective June 30. Clay has been a significant voice in Kentucky sports reporting for over 40 years, expressing deep passion for sports and his hometown teams. A Central Kentucky native and University of Kentucky graduate, Clay was honored by being inducted into the U.S. Basketball Writers Association Hall of Fame in April.

stories.headline: Kennedy makes ‘clean sweep’ of key vaccine advisory panel
stories.summary: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced plans to replace all members of the advisory panel responsible for vaccine guidelines, a move experts say is unprecedented. This committee advises the CDC on vaccine use. Kennedy cited a need to restore public trust in vaccine science, emphasizing the importance of unbiased and transparent processes free from conflicts of interest.

stories.headline: Vacation rental rules challenged
stories.summary: Pinellas County officials are trying to enforce stricter regulations on vacation rentals, including requiring owners to register for a certificate of use and safety inspection and limiting occupancy to 10 persons. However, some rental owners are threatening legal action against the county over these new rules. The challenge highlights ongoing tensions over vacation rental regulations and enforcement in the community.

stories.headline: Tampa City Council member Gwen Henderson dies at 60
stories.summary: Gwendolyn Henderson, a Tampa City Council member known for her dedication to public education, economic opportunity, and championing African-American culture and history, passed away at age 60 due to natural causes. Henderson was recognized for her passion and impact on the community. A memorial announcement was made by her family and community leaders.

stories.headline: Top Florida officials OK buying 340 acres from luxury golf developer
stories.summary: Governor Ron DeSantis, Attorney General James Uthmeier, and Agriculture Commissioner Wilton Simpson approved the purchase of 340 acres of forest land in Hernando County for conservation. The land was previously part of a luxury golf resort project, Cabot Citrus, which had received initial state approval to reduce the acreage it reserved for public use. The purchase means the land will be added to conservation areas rather than swapped for other lands.

stories.headline: His brother died at 16. 5 years later, they walked the stage together
stories.summary: Lawson Boeth honored his late brother Walter, who died of a fentanyl overdose at age 16, by carrying a posthumous diploma for him during his own graduation ceremony from Newsome High School. Despite his grief, Lawson managed to graduate and paid tribute to his brother who he believed would have supported him if he were alive.

stories.headline: Migrant's detention after posting bail puts focus on Montco policy
stories.summary: Andrea Lozano-Alanis was handed over to ICE agents soon after posting a $7,000 bail in Montgomery County, a policy that allows ICE to take custody shortly after bail is posted. This practice has angered immigration activists and raised concerns over rights of undocumented individuals who meet bail conditions but are still detained due to local policies. Lozano-Alanis now faces deportation to Mexico following the sequence of events that led to her ICE detention.

stories.headline: Newsom moves to block use of troops in raids
stories.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom asked a federal court to block the Trump administration from using the National Guard and Marines to assist with immigration raids in Los Angeles, arguing that it would only heighten tensions. Newsom filed the emergency request following orders from President Donald Trump to deploy troops for immigration law enforcement. The court documents argued that the use of troops on immigration raids would escalate tensions and provoke civil unrest, with Marines and National Guard troops mostly absent from street protests so far.

stories.headline: 4-alarm blaze in W. Philly probed as arson
stories.summary: A four-alarm fire gutted a vacant West Philadelphia apartment building over the weekend and was deliberately set according to the fire marshal. The blaze, at a four-story building owned by landlord Phil Pulley, required the response of over 150 firefighters and support personnel but caused no injuries. The building had been vacant since residents were evicted in 2018 and had numerous code violations and inspection issues. The Southwest Detectives Division has opened an arson investigation into the blaze.

stories.headline: Lurie, family give $50M to fuel autism research
stories.summary: Philadelphia Eagles owner Jeffrey Lurie and his family donated $50 million to accelerate autism research through Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and Penn Medicine. The donation aims to create a dedicated center to study causes and treatment options for autism. The Lurie Autism Institute will build on existing research at these institutions to understand the neurological basis of autism and offer improved diagnostic and treatment methods. The donation marks a significant commitment to autism research supporting individuals with autism spectrum disorder.

stories.headline: Newsom seeks halt to troop deployment
stories.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom filed an emergency motion to temporarily restrain President Donald Trump and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth from deploying Marines and the National Guard to Los Angeles. The motion argues federal overreach as troops continue to deploy amid immigration enforcement protests. Newsom stated the federal government is militarizing against American citizens, calling the move unprecedented and threatening democracy.

stories.headline: Democrat Wahls to run for U.S. Senate against Ernst
stories.summary: Iowa state Senator Zach Wahls announced his candidacy for the U.S. Senate, challenging incumbent Republican Joni Ernst in the 2026 election. Wahls, from Coralville, joins a competitive field of candidates vying for the Senate seat. The race is anticipated to be closely contested, representing a significant political development in Iowa ahead of the next election cycle.

stories.headline: Dawn of a new era for birthing centers
stories.summary: A Des Moines midwife who sued the state to open a new birthing center has won a legislative victory after losing in court, encouraging midwives and others. Caitlin Hainley of the Des Moines Midwife Collective aimed to open a single-family home birthing center with tubs and equipment for a comfortable, home-like environment. Though the collective lost in court, legislators passed a bill signed by Gov. Kim Reynolds defining such birth centers as distinct health facilities, facilitating their operation.

stories.headline: State special hunt auction underway with eight packages
stories.summary: The New Mexico Department of Game and Fish has started auctioning special hunt packages for elk, mule deer, and pronghorn to fund wildlife conservation efforts. Proceeds will go to the Game Protection Fund to support conservation and fish license sales. The Governor's Special Hunt Auction closes on June 22, offering hunters an opportunity to acquire sought-after hunting licenses.

stories.headline: TROOPS ON U.S. SOIL: Marines deployed in L.A. as Trump claims emergency on ICE protests that local officials say are in hand
stories.summary: Approximately 7,000 Marines arrived in Los Angeles to respond to protests triggered by President Trump's immigration enforcement actions, including deployment of 4,000 National Guard troops. The presence of active-duty troops in U.S. cities has sparked concern among local officials, legal experts, and Democrats. The Trump administration asserts this is a novel approach to circumvent restrictions on domestic use of military, while critics warn of escalating tensions and dangerous civilian oversight.

stories.headline: Santa Fe man with family in Gaza: 'They're just people'
stories.summary: Said Assali, a Palestinian American and Santa Fe resident, shares his personal experience with family living in Gaza amid the Israel-Hamas conflict. He discusses the struggles his relatives face, including lack of food, housing, and exposure to violence, expressing empathy and emphasizing their humanity beyond political and media portrayals.

stories.headline: Area Jewish community shaken by recent attacks
stories.summary: Jewish communities in the U.S. are experiencing increased insecurity following recent violent attacks, including an incident in Boulder, Colorado, and the killing of two staff members of the Israeli Embassy in Washington, D.C. Local Jewish leaders have heightened security at synagogues and emphasize the importance of vigilance and safety. The article highlights the ongoing concerns about anti-Semitism and the need for continued protection of Jewish communities.

stories.headline: MDOT proposes tighter rules for rest areas, carpool lots
stories.summary: The Michigan Department of Transportation (MDOT) is seeking to prohibit people from camping and living in their cars at state rest areas and carpool lots for extended periods. While temporary rest would be permitted, tents and extended stays would be banned. This comes as MDOT seeks to establish enforceable rules to manage complaints and public safety concerns.

stories.headline: Scammers use AI to steal college financial aid
stories.summary: The article discusses the rise of fraud involving stolen identities to obtain federal student aid, facilitated by AI and the popularity of online classes. An example is Heather Brady, who had fake college loans taken out in her name. The U.S. Education Department is working on new verification requirements to counter this trend, which has caused millions in losses, especially in states like California.

stories.headline: Another Chinese academic nabbed for smuggling foreign material
stories.summary: A second Chinese academic linked to the University of Michigan has been charged with smuggling materials, including roundworms, to the United States. The academic, Chengxuan Han, is being investigated for sending nutrient-rich materials and nematodes allegedly to a lab associated with the university. This follows earlier similar cases and highlights ongoing enforcement actions by U.S. authorities.

stories.headline: 'Some cry all day.' ICE detainees face harsh conditions in Miami federal detention facility
stories.summary: Migrant detainees at a Miami federal detention center experience overcrowding and harsh conditions including lack of adequate water, food, medical care, and use of force by officers. A Miami Herald investigation uncovered severe mistreatment and legal challenges faced by detainees, exacerbated by mass deportation policies and administrative failures. The situation raises serious human rights concerns and calls for federal accountability and reform of detention practices.

stories.headline: Latinas for Trump founder condemns White House immigration crackdown
stories.summary: A Miami Republican who co-founded the group Latinas for Trump criticized President Donald Trump's mass-deportation strategy and immigration enforcement actions as harmful, uncalled for, and inhumane. She highlighted the stress and uncertainty caused in immigrant communities within South Florida and called for a more balanced approach as the administration continues to ramp up immigration arrests and deportations nationwide.

stories.headline: 'Not a culinary wasteland' Can Michelin make Fort Lauderdale a dining destination?
stories.summary: Despite Fort Lauderdale's beautiful natural surroundings, the local dining scene has been less prominent compared to other major cities. However, the impact of the 2020 pandemic and Miami's gaining of Michelin stars signaled renewed interest in elevating Fort Lauderdale's restaurant quality. Chef Rino Carbon, among others, is optimistic about the city's gastronomy future as it evolves to compete more seriously in the culinary arena.

stories.headline: Help ICE or lose your job, Florida attorney general tells Broward Sheriff Gregory Tony
stories.summary: Florida Attorney General James Uthmeier warned Broward Sheriff Gregory Tony that he must prioritize arresting undocumented immigrants or risk losing his job. Uthmeier expressed strong opposition to Tony's reported refusal to cooperate with ICE in Broward County, emphasizing that crimes in the county will not be tolerated regardless of immigration status. The conflict highlights ongoing tensions between local law enforcement and federal immigration policies under the current administration.

stories.headline: Alison Arngrim Reflects on Life as the 'Little House' Mean Girl in One-Woman Show
stories.summary: Alison Arngrim shares insights and reflections on her life and career, focusing on her role as the 'mean girl' in the television show 'Little House on the Prairie,' through a one-woman show. The performance highlights her personal and professional journey.

stories.headline: Attorney for R. Kelly Claims Singer's Life in Danger, Seeks Help from Judge, Trump
stories.summary: R. Kelly's attorney has claimed that the singer's life is in danger and is requesting assistance from a judge as well as former President Trump to ensure his client's safety. This development adds another layer of complexity to the ongoing legal matters surrounding the singer.

stories.headline: Terrifying Turn
stories.summary: A car drove through an anti-ICE protest as thousands rallied downtown in solidarity with Los Angeles. The incident caused alarm among protesters and bystanders at the event, raising concerns about safety during demonstrations.

stories.headline: Park District Shuns Ad Against Antisemitism — and Ketchup on Hot Dogs
stories.summary: The Park District has chosen to reject an advertisement campaign aimed at fighting antisemitism and another related to ketchup on hot dogs. This decision has sparked discussions about community values and advertising standards within the district.

stories.headline: Chicago may force Uber, Lyft to hike driver pay
stories.summary: Chicago city officials are considering an ordinance that would require ride-share companies like Uber and Lyft to increase driver pay. The proposed change aims to address the costs drivers face, ensuring a minimum wage and raising per-ride payments. While the measure would financially impact companies and possibly lead to higher ride fares, city authorities argue it is necessary to support drivers financially amid rising operating costs. The ordinance will be reviewed by the City Council's Workforce Development Committee.

stories.headline: Troubled tech firm used insider lobbyist
stories.summary: Tyler Technologies, a Texas-based tech contractor, enlisted Jay Doherty, a politically connected lobbyist previously convicted in the ComEd corruption scheme, to help build business in Cook County. Doherty's lobbying efforts included gaining access to influential Illinois figures, enabling Tyler to secure contracts and navigate local government influence. Though Doherty had controversial ties, no direct connection was found between his work for Tyler and his prior indictment. The firm reportedly used insider influence to advance its interests in the county.

stories.headline: AI is learning to farm
stories.summary: As labor costs increase, agricultural engineers are exploring the use of artificial intelligence to meet farming demands more efficiently. At Flamm Orchards in Cobden, Illinois, temporary farm workers from Oaxaca, Mexico, help with peak season tasks, but rising labor expenses have prompted the Chicago Tribune to explore automation possibilities. Experts suggest that advanced AI could help manage crops and labor shortages, providing a sustainable solution for future agricultural challenges caused by rising costs and labor scarcity.

stories.headline: Political cloud hangs over Army’s birthday parade
stories.summary: Military officials and experts express concern over the Army's 250th birthday parade in Washington, D.C., noting that the military presence and celebration coincides with political undertones. President Donald Trump’s 79th birthday falls the same day as the parade, causing worries that the event will be politicized. The deployment of active-duty troops, including the Army's 79th Infantry Brigade Combat Team, has drawn scrutiny about the appropriateness of the celebrations amidst current tensions and challenges faced by the armed forces.

stories.headline: ‘THEY NEED TO SEE ... WE’RE NOT SCARED’
stories.summary: Thousands of people protested in San Francisco and Los Angeles in response to President Donald Trump's immigration policies and the deployment of National Guard troops to Los Angeles. While protests remained largely peaceful, some areas saw an increase in tensions and violence. Demonstrators rallied against immigration raids and Trump's administration, emphasizing their resilience and refusal to be intimidated by the government's actions.

stories.headline: Squid may be state’s last lucrative catch
stories.summary: California fishermen face economic challenges as salmon and Dungeness crab seasons remain closed, leaving squid as the only promising species for a profitable catch. Chinese tariffs and other market pressures threaten prices, but fishermen hope that squid, especially Monterey squid, could offer some financial relief. The harvesting of squid is vital given the closures of other key fishing seasons and the uncertain future of the fishing industry in the state.

stories.headline: Waymos avoid some areas after backlash
stories.summary: Following increased tensions and opposition to immigration raids in Los Angeles, Waymo self-driving cars have been restricted from certain areas of the city. This move comes after the vehicles were targeted and caught in the middle of protests and backlash. The restriction aims to reduce tensions and manage public safety while the situation develops.

stories.headline: Noem called for military arrests in L.A.
stories.summary: One day before the Trump administration deployed U.S. Marines to confront protesters in Los Angeles, U.S. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem urged Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to use the military to detain or arrest protesters, calling it a 'grave escalation.' Noem's letter requested Pentagon direction to the Department of Defense to deploy forces to either detain or arrest 'lawbreakers,' escalating the federal response to protests against immigration policies.

stories.headline: Deployed troops ‘underprepared’
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's rush to deploy California National Guard troops to Los Angeles has left dozens of soldiers without adequate sleeping arrangements and basic necessities, forced to stay in basements or loading docks. The deployment lacked federal funding for essentials like food and shelter, causing frustration among the troops. Senior military leaders warned that the California troops could continue sleeping in unsafe conditions unless federal officials made a permanent decision to support them.

stories.headline: Hegseth hearing turns testy
stories.summary: During a Congressional hearing, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth faced tough questions from Democrats regarding the defense budget, particularly about troop deployments to Los Angeles and other controversial issues. The intense exchange reflects ongoing partisan disagreements over military spending and national defense priorities as lawmakers seek more transparency and accountability.

stories.headline: Vote sets sights on gay marriage
stories.summary: The Southern Baptist Convention voted to endorse overturning the 2015 Supreme Court decision that legalized gay marriage. The resolution, supported by representatives from 46,876 churches, criticized declining fertility rates and the normalization of transgender ideology. This move came during the Southern Baptist Convention's annual meeting in Dallas, reflecting ongoing debates within the denomination regarding gender and marriage issues.

stories.headline: Duo keeps goals in sight
stories.summary: Nina Vaca and Dan Hunt, co-chairs of the North Texas FIFA World Cup Organizing Committee, expressed confidence in delivering a top-tier World Cup event in Dallas. With extensive experience in business and community involvement, they highlighted the importance of integrity, legacy, and long-term commitment. The organizers emphasized teamwork and detailed planning for the 2026 FIFA World Cup matches that will take place across multiple countries including the U.S., Mexico, and Canada.

stories.headline: English scores down statewide
stories.summary: Texas high school students showed improvements in Algebra I but experienced declines in English performance on the STAAR standardized tests, according to recent results. Despite some gains in other subjects like biology, there was concern about English proficiency as students continue to struggle to meet grade-level expectations. Texas Education Commissioner Mike Morath highlighted the need for continued efforts to improve academic excellence statewide.

stories.headline: Indy group protests Trump's travel ban
stories.summary: More than 100 people gathered at Indianapolis International Airport on June 9 to protest President Donald Trump’s travel ban barring citizens from 12 countries, including Afghanistan, Chad, and Iran. The ban also places restrictions on nationals from several other countries. Protesters, including members of the Indiana Muslim Advocacy Network and Exodus Refugee, expressed concerns about the ban's impact on immigrants, families, and communities, calling for the lifting of the ban in support of immigrant rights.

stories.headline: Aide accuser ousted mid-meeting
stories.summary: Lauren Roberts, one of three women who alleged sexual harassment and abuse by former top aide to Indianapolis Mayor Joe Hogsett, was forcibly removed from the June 9 City-County Council meeting by sheriff's deputies after exceeding a two-minute time limit while trying to voice her concerns about Hogsett’s staff. The event was marked by interruptions, shouts, and a forceful removal as Roberts refused to stop speaking.

stories.headline: 'Everyone’s thrilled for Herbie'
stories.summary: Reggie Miller handed Herb Simon the Eastern Conference trophy after the Pacers' May 31 win over the Knicks. The Pacers' NBA Finals run highlights the quiet devotion of owner Herb Simon, who has been a key figure behind the team's success over decades. Despite his reserved nature, Simon’s leadership and long-time commitment to the franchise are being celebrated as the team advances to the 2025 NBA Finals.

stories.headline: Combs’ ex continues with her testimony
stories.summary: During cross-examination, Sean 'Diddy' Combs' ex-girlfriend stated she performed sexual acts with male sex workers because it made her feel loved by him. This is part of ongoing legal proceedings involving the pop music star.

stories.headline: NIH director says he's open to increased budget
stories.summary: Jay Bhattacharya, NIH director, has expressed willingness to increase the agency's budget from Congress, amidst discussions with Republicans and Democrats who have questioned the NIH's direction and spending.

stories.headline: Alderman Gay arrested after traffic stop
stories.summary: Annapolis Alderman DaJuan Gay, a Democrat, was arrested after a traffic stop early Tuesday morning. The arrest was confirmed by a spokesperson, and further details are being awaited.

stories.headline: Helping hand
stories.summary: Steven Jones, pastor of Spirit Of Faith Deliverance Church, gathered food at the Maryland Food Bank to support the church's pantry efforts. The Maryland Food Bank announced a $750,000 grant from Walmart and Feeding America to support food rescue efforts, aiding in providing fresh, frozen, and shelf-stable foods to food pantries and community partners.

stories.headline: Police ID victim of spear stabbing
stories.summary: Howard County Police confirmed the identity of a Columbia man who was fatally stabbed with a spear inside his home. The victim, Samuel Louie Booker IV, was critically injured after a double-edged spear attack. Police and the Maryland Attorney General's Office are investigating the incident.

stories.headline: Governor says he ordered agency head’s resignation
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore stated in an interview that he ordered the resignation of Vincent Schiraldi from Maryland's Department of Juvenile Services. Moore expressed that his patience was running low and highlighted concerns over juvenile crime rates. The conversation clarified the governor's role and intent behind the leadership change in the juvenile services department.

stories.headline: State leaders praise naming of Tolentino for DJS role
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore's decision to replace Vincent Schiraldi with Betsy Fox Tolentino as head of juvenile services was applauded by state leaders, prosecutors, and lawmakers. The appointment reflects efforts to improve leadership and policies in the Department of Juvenile Services, aiming to increase accountability and move faster toward reform.

stories.headline: Trump says he will ‘liberate’ LA
stories.summary: President Donald Trump called protesters 'foreign enemy animals' in a speech at Fort Bragg marking the 250th anniversary of the U.S. Army. He criticized immigration enforcement protests in California and announced the restoration of Confederate names on military bases. The speech previewed a military parade planned in Washington, D.C., and highlighted his administration's stance against unrest and law enforcement challenges nationwide.

stories.headline: Order prompts chair to quit
stories.summary: The chair of the Naval Academy History Department resigned after reportedly being ordered by the academy's superintendent to remove a previously approved paper from the list of symposium presentations. Tom McCarthy's resignation comes amid controversy over removing a paper discussing scholarship and harm to the department's reputation, with McCarthy stating he could not agree with the decision and chose to end his association with the implementation.

stories.headline: DHS official downplays Trump loyalist's anti-terrorism post
stories.summary: Thomas Fugate III, a 22-year-old Trump loyalist appointed to a Homeland Security position focusing on countering violent extremism, was hired despite questionable background. The Department of Homeland Security defended his role, describing its Center for Prevention Programs and Partnerships as robust and vital to its mission. Questions remain about the effectiveness and focus of the center following Fugate's appointment and the Trump administration's approach to the issue.

stories.headline: Talarico weighing a run for Senate
stories.summary: State Representative James Talarico is considering running for the U.S. Senate seat held by Senator John Cornyn, who faces a Republican primary challenge. Talarico, a former schoolteacher and Austin Democrat, has gained attention for vocal opposition to Governor Greg Abbott's policies, including private school vouchers and education debates. While several Democrats have expressed interest in the race, Talarico's potential candidacy adds to the developing competition for the 2026 Senate election.

stories.headline: California governor asks federal court to block use of troops in immigration raids
stories.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom requested a federal court to block the Trump administration from deploying National Guard and Marines for immigration raids in Los Angeles. The governor cited public safety concerns and requested a hearing as protests against immigration enforcement continue in the city. The federal government defends the deployment as lawful and necessary to enforce immigration laws.

stories.headline: 12 are arrested in downtown protests
stories.summary: Hundreds of people took to the streets of downtown Austin in response to National Guard deployment in Los Angeles amid immigration raids. The protest, largely peaceful, saw dozens arrested during clashes with police using tear gas and chemical irritants to disperse smaller groups of demonstrators. Organizers criticized the Trump administration's immigration policies and the deployment of troops. The situation highlights statewide tensions over immigration enforcement measures and civil response.

stories.headline: Rocket weighs future of Detroit’s PGA Tour stop
stories.summary: When PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan visited Detroit in fall 2021, he announced an extension of the Rocket Classic, now called the Detroit Classic, until 2026. However, questions arise regarding the long-term future of this longstanding tournament, which will end after the 2026 event. The Rocket is exploring options to continue beyond 2027 but currently faces uncertainty about its continuation on the PGA Tour calendar.

stories.headline: Downtown LA curfew issued as the Guard steps into action
stories.summary: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass has imposed a curfew on downtown Los Angeles to curb vandalism and looting amidst recent protests and unrest. The curfew, effective from 8 p.m. Tuesday to 6 a.m. Wednesday, covers a 1-square mile area that includes protest sites where unrest escalated. The curfew does not apply to residents in designated areas or authorized personnel. The city has seen increased law enforcement presence to maintain order following recent disturbances.

stories.headline: Faith-based groups emerge as key in mayoral primary
stories.summary: Neighborhood development in Detroit has seen faith-based groups become influential in the city's mayoral primary elections, especially in districts within and outside downtown. Many mayoral hopefuls, including City Council President Mary Sheffield, emphasize the role of these groups in providing social services and community development. The primary candidates focus on issues like reviving commercial corridors and repairing homes, highlighting the importance of religious organizations in the local political landscape.

stories.headline: GM to move $4B in production to U.S.
stories.summary: General Motors plans to invest $4 billion to shift production from Mexico to three plants in the United States, including relocating its shut-down Orion Assembly plant in suburban Detroit. Full-size SUVs and light-duty pickups will be produced in Orion as GM refocuses on electric vehicles, including the gas-powered Equinox compact SUV and the gas-powdered Blazer. The move underscores GM's confidence in American innovation and manufacturing expertise.

stories.headline: Congress sharply questions Defense head on deploying troops to LA and spending
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth faced intense scrutiny from lawmakers over his decision to deploy troops to Los Angeles amid immigration-related protests. Members of Congress expressed frustration over the lack of full defense budget from the Trump administration and raised concerns about the spending of $134 million related to the troop deployment. The confrontation involved heated exchanges between committee members and Hegseth.

stories.headline: Trump tests federal power as 700 Marines arrive in Los Angeles area
stories.summary: About 700 Marines and approximately 4,000 National Guard troops arrived in the Los Angeles area to respond to protests related to President Donald Trump's immigration enforcement actions. State and local officials criticized the deployment as excessive and inflammatory. The Trump administration justified this as a necessary measure amid ongoing tensions and considered a new legal theory that may challenge existing restrictions on domestic military use.

stories.headline: Trump fires TVA board member
stories.summary: President Donald Trump terminated Beth Geer, former Vice President Al Gore's chief of staff, from the Tennessee Valley Authority board. Geer's term was set to expire in May, and she was one of several members appointed by President Joe Biden. The TVA cited no public reason for the firing, which reversed prior board decisions during Trump's administration. The move reduces board quorum and impacts approval of new policies requiring quarterly public meetings.

stories.headline: Congressman seeks a more public TVA
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Tim Burchett introduced a bill requiring the Tennessee Valley Authority to hold nearly all its board meetings in public to increase transparency. The legislation passed the House with a voice vote and aims to expand the TVA Act of 1933 by mandating public access to board meetings at least four times a year. The TVA, a publicly owned utility, already posts some quarterly board meetings online but holds most committee meetings privately.

stories.headline: When tech support is the real problem
stories.summary: Scammers are increasingly targeting vulnerable individuals by posing as tech support helpers. The scams involve elaborate ruses leading victims to hand over sensitive information and money, sometimes over extended periods. Victims recount shock and fear upon realizing they have been scammed, highlighting the growing sophistication of tech scams and the need for greater awareness and protections.

stories.headline: Deep-blue Calif. revels in making Trump see red
stories.summary: California, a deeply Democratic state, has become a symbolic battleground reflecting strong opposition to Donald Trump. After losing by a large margin in the 2016 election, Trump has had a difficult relationship with the state, which has resisted his policies. Recent events show potential political fallout for Trump in a state with significant population and progressive values, indicating ongoing political tension.

stories.headline: Some are left out as cities come back
stories.summary: Amid economic recovery and rising housing prices in former industrial hubs near Boston, homelessness has sharply increased. Factors include long-term decline of working-class jobs, high housing costs, and insufficient affordable housing options. City leaders acknowledge a critical mass of homelessness but struggle to find effective solutions as many individuals cycle through shelters and subsidized apartments.

stories.headline: Trump tests boundaries by calling in Marines
stories.summary: About 700 Marines arrived in the Los Angeles area in response to widespread protests against President Trump's immigration enforcement actions. The deployment, alongside 4,000 National Guard troops, sparked concerns and opposition from city officials, local experts, and Democrats who fear the use of federal troops will escalate tensions. Curfews and major protests also occurred across multiple cities nationwide.

stories.headline: N.E. voters now even more down on president
stories.summary: A new Suffolk University/Boston Globe poll shows that voters across Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Rhode Island feel the country is headed in the wrong direction, with worsening pessimism about the economy and immigration policies under the Trump administration. Approval ratings for the president remain low and many now believe the country is on the wrong track across all three states.

stories.headline: Glowing axolotls shed light on limb regeneration
stories.summary: Scientists studying axolotls, a species known for their remarkable ability to regenerate limbs, have used genetically engineered glowing axolotls to identify and understand the cellular and molecular processes involved in regeneration. This research may help answer questions about how humans might regain lost limbs or heal injuries. The axolotl's unique biology is becoming a hopeful model for regenerative medicine.

stories.headline: On the box: D.C. court officials repeatedly lost track of teens wearing ankle monitors. The timing was deadly.
stories.summary: D.C. court officials lost track of Maurice Jackson Jr. and others wearing ankle monitors, missing crucial times when they were out of community supervision. Maurice was charged as a habitual runaway and had been previously stopped by police. After being released, he was found dead in a violent crime scene, underscoring serious oversight failures by juvenile officials in tracking monitored teens, with tragic outcomes.

stories.headline: Spain weighs criminal charges in deadly floods
stories.summary: After deadly floods in Valencia caused by torrential rains and poor management, officials are investigating potential criminal charges against those responsible. The floods killed 228 people and caused widespread destruction. A judge has been interviewing survivors and collecting evidence to potentially indict officials for recklessness and negligence that contributed to the disaster, aiming to hold accountable those whose decisions led to the tragedy.

stories.headline: Trump: Show of force is a warning to other cities
stories.summary: President Donald Trump issued a stern warning to cities opposing federal immigration policies following additional protests against federal immigration. The demonstrations, including enforcement raids that spurred hundreds of arrests, highlighted tensions over immigration enforcement across multiple U.S. cities. Trump called those participating "paid troublemakers" and emphasized his administration's resolve to crack down on what he described as a 'foreign invasion'.

stories.headline: Ramp-up will see allies' citizens sent to Guantánamo
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans to start transferring potentially thousands of foreigners from the U.S. to the Guantánamo Bay military base, including nationals from allied European countries. The process includes medical screenings for around 9,000 individuals and is being handled with high secrecy. Allies such as Britain, France, and others are unlikely to be notified of these plans, raising concerns about diplomatic communication and human rights.

stories.headline: Big parade started out as Army's modest idea
stories.summary: The idea for the big parade began as a modest military event for the Army's 250th birthday on June 12, 2024, initially involving about 300 soldiers and civilian personnel with limited displays. The concept evolved dramatically after President Donald Trump was elected, with preparations including tanks in D.C., flyovers, and thousands of troops and participants, turning it into one of the grandest military events seen in Trump’s first term.

stories.headline: New coach looks forward
stories.summary: The new Suns head coach Jordan Ott is focused on moving forward with the team rather than dwelling on the past, expressing optimism about the future.

stories.headline: Moving ahead with plan
stories.summary: Taser manufacturer Axon will move forward with developing nearly 2,000 apartments and condos after negotiations with Scottsdale fell apart.

stories.headline: Advocates for migrants protest Homeland Security activity
stories.summary: Pro-immigrant activists in Arizona protested heightened Homeland Security activity and ICE workplace raids, following alerts and reports of ongoing enforcement operations. Early on June 10, immigrant advocates tracked federal agents from Homeland Security Investigations during a convoy and protested near a Walmart Neighborhood Market along Pecan Avenue. The group chased down tips of ICE activity and posted updates via social media.

stories.headline: Regulators face GOP primary showdown
stories.summary: State Representative Ralph Heap plans to run for a seat on the Arizona Corporation Commission, setting up a Republican primary race against fellow conservatives for key state leadership roles. Incumbents Kevin Thompson and Nick Myers intend to seek nomination for two open seats in 2026. Some candidates have resisted efforts by certain groups to focus on environmental and diversity issues amid the campaign.

stories.headline: For first time in decades ... the border is silent
stories.summary: Border Patrol agents have encountered significantly fewer migrants and asylum seekers at the U.S.-Mexico border compared to a year ago. Where over 100,000 migrants crossed monthly just a year ago, the number now is less than 10,000. This change reflects the fulfillment of President Trump's campaign promise to reduce migrant flow, with similar conditions observed across the border from California to Texas.

stories.headline: Legislative session was a huge win for Abbott
stories.summary: Governor Greg Abbott has completed his fourth term as governor with significant legislative successes. Despite opposition from within his own party, Abbott secured key priorities including long-sought bail reforms, infrastructure investments, and school voucher legislation. His strong campaign efforts and political strategy were highlighted as instrumental in achieving these outcomes, marking an important session in his career.

stories.headline: Newsom asks court to block use of troops in California ICE raids
stories.summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom has asked a federal court to block the Trump administration from deploying the National Guard and Marines for immigration raids in Los Angeles. He argues that such deployment would escalate tensions and insists the state should handle these issues. Newsom's move is a response to the administration's plans to send thousands of troops to assist with immigration enforcement operations in California.

stories.headline: Ex-board member: no reasons cited for removal
stories.summary: Adam Rivon, a recently ousted member of the Houston ISD Board of Managers, stated that no clear reasons were given for his removal. Rivon suggested that assumptions and political considerations influenced the decision. Texas Education Agency Commissioner Mike Morath unexpectedly removed Rivon and extended the district's state intervention through June 2027. The situation has triggered questions about the transparency and motivations behind board member removals.

stories.headline: High school STAAR scores rise for HISD
stories.summary: Houston Independent School District (HISD) high school students showed improvement in STAAR subject test results in Algebra 1 and Biology two years into intervention efforts. The Texas Education Agency released results indicating that HISD students surpassed statewide averages in biology and Algebra 1, although scores in English subjects remained mixed. These gains highlight progress amid ongoing efforts to boost educational outcomes.

stories.headline: ICE is ‘out ... catching low-hanging fruit’
stories.summary: Plainclothes immigration agents have arrested at least six people in the past two days at a Houston immigration court, focusing on cases with pending asylum claims. The arrests occurred at the South Gessner Road Immigration Court, where agents used tactics such as escorting individuals through parking garages to avoid detection. Cesar Espinoza, executive director of FIEL, described the situation as unsettling because the agents took advantage of the court setting, restricting the movement of people heading to their hearings.

stories.headline: Meth, not migrants, prompted federal raids across metro
stories.summary: Federal searches in several Twin Cities metro areas were sparked by the discovery of over 900 pounds of methamphetamine linked to a drug trafficking investigation. The raids, authorized by a judge, focused on places unrelated to immigration enforcement and did not target migrants. Charges were filed against an individual in connection with meth possession and assaulting officers. The federal raids disrupted operations of restaurants linked to the meth trafficking network and were contrary to some public assumptions about migrant involvement.

stories.headline: 700 Marines arrive in L.A. as test of power
stories.summary: Around 700 Marines arrived in Los Angeles in response to protests over President Donald Trump's immigration enforcement actions. The deployment tests the use of military forces on U.S. soil and responds to demands for meaningful change amid protests. The Marines joined about 4,000 National Guard troops already deployed in Los Angeles. California officials stressed restrictions on troop use domestically, and the Trump administration's actions sparked debate among experts and city officials about civil rights and federal authority.

stories.headline: With compromises, state budget finalized
stories.summary: Minnesota lawmakers finalized a $66 billion two-year budget after a lengthy special session marked by compromises on spending, infrastructure projects, employee layoffs, and public school funding policies. The legislative session was contentious, with intense negotiations behind closed doors. The budget includes a bonding bill to fund projects since 2023 and contains provisions related to teacher pensions and public employee protections, though some policy ideas for public schools mostly fizzled.

stories.headline: Frey mandates police reforms with order
stories.summary: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey issued an executive order directing city staff to implement the terms of the federal police reform agreement abandoned by the Trump administration. The order instructs the City Attorney's Office to create a formal index of all reform items from the dissolved federal consent decree except those already in or in conflict with a separate settlement with the Minnesota Department of Human Rights. Frey's order also asks for advice on how to monitor the implementation of the federal terms. It emphasizes full cooperation from city leaders and employees and aims to continue pursuing meaningful police reforms despite challenges from the federal administration.

stories.headline: Troop deployments to L.A. thrust U.S. military chiefs into spotlight
stories.summary: The deployment of active-duty Marines to Los Angeles to address immigration and protest violence has drawn national attention. Military leaders, including Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Dan Caine, face scrutiny over the deployment amid concern about rising tensions in California. The situation could extinguish as political fallout unfolds in the coming days.
people: Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Dan Caine

stories.headline: Sheinbaum wants no taxes on remittances
stories.summary: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum has opposed a proposal in President Trump's Big Beautiful Bill that would impose a 3.5% tax on money that Mexicans send abroad. Remittances are a significant source of foreign income in Mexico and Central America, and Sheinbaum argues that taxing them would harm economies that rely heavily on this money.

stories.headline: Conservatives in South Korea fear judiciary branch at risk under Lee
stories.summary: South Korean conservatives express concern that President Lee Jae-myung and his Democratic Party's efforts to remake the courts could threaten the judiciary's independence. The political landscape is uncertain with the ruling Democratic Party controlling key legislative bodies, and fears are rising over potential aggressive judicial reforms.

stories.headline: Newsom bid to evict troops rejected
stories.summary: A federal judge granted President Trump at least two more days to delay California's request to remove federal troops deployed in Los Angeles amid protests. The city's efforts to evict the National Guard and Marines were denied as clashes between demonstrators and law enforcement persisted. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass issued a curfew and called for calm following ongoing protests and looting.

stories.headline: Democratic Party down and out in Washington
stories.summary: Democrats have struggled to connect with voters in 2025 as they try to recalibrate their message but continue defending the status quo, with the Democratic Party's key message being that President Trump is worsening America. The party is facing difficulties due to shifting public sentiment and internal dissatisfaction with the current federal government leadership.

stories.headline: Moreno defends his candidacy
stories.summary: After controversy emerged from a social media post dividing retired police officer Tony Moreno and the local GOP committee, Moreno defended his position as the Republican candidate for Pittsburgh mayor. He reaffirmed his commitment to the city and campaign despite criticism from the GOP committee, stating he has no plans to withdraw and is seeking mayoral office in the upcoming election.

stories.headline: Oakmont businesses hoping for a bump
stories.summary: Oakmont is expected to experience increased economic activity this week with the approach of the 2025 U.S. Open golf tournament. Local businesses like The Oaks Theater are preparing special themed events tied to the championship to attract visitors. Signs welcoming golfers and fans are visible throughout the town, with hopes of boosting local business during the tournament.

stories.headline: ‘FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL’
stories.summary: Quarterback Aaron Rodgers is adjusting to the Pittsburgh Steelers' ways during minicamp as he begins learning the team after being traded. Rodgers describes the experience as a 'first day of school,' with everything feeling new and unfamiliar, including not knowing many players' names. Despite challenges, Rodgers is excited and committed to learning and contributing to the new team.

stories.headline: VIOLENCE TRIGGERS CURFEW ORDER
stories.summary: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass issued a curfew for downtown Los Angeles after widespread looting and vandalism. The curfew, effective from 8 p.m. to 6 a.m., covers an area of roughly 500 square miles and aims to safeguard lives and property following several days of unrest. National Guard troops began protecting immigration agents in Los Angeles as the situation escalated.

stories.headline: Jewish congregations to merge
stories.summary: Two historic Reform Jewish congregations in Pittsburgh's East End will soon come together under one roof after approving a merger. Congregants of Rodef Shalom and Temple Sinai voted in favor of unification, marking a significant step nearly 80 years after the congregations split. This unification is seen as a historic milestone in the city's Jewish history and aims to strengthen the community.

stories.headline: Will Newsom’s feud with Trump over LA protests help or hurt?
stories.summary: Governor Gavin Newsom faced criticism after abandoning the ceasefire with President Donald Trump over January’s wildfires and ongoing debates about immigration protests in Los Angeles. The recent weekend protest included clashes with federal troops and sparked a media-driven political playbook featuring social media campaigns and interviews. Newsom rejected federal requests to order Pentagon troops to suppress protests and has challenged the legality of the National Guard's deployment in the city, leading to ongoing tension between state and federal authorities.

stories.headline: Democratic lawmakers reach state budget deal
stories.summary: Democratic lawmakers reached a spending agreement to fill California's roughly $12 billion deficit, rejecting proposed cuts to health care and social services. The budget deal includes a freeze on Medi-Cal enrollment for undocumented adults, an 8% cut to higher education systems, and salary freezes for state workers. Legislators must pass the budget by June 15, and Governor Gavin Newsom must sign it by the end of the month. The deal comes amid challenges from federal and state pressures and ongoing budget deficits.

stories.headline: California Senate elects Monique Limón as next leader
stories.summary: California Democratic leaders elected State Senator Monique Limón, D-Goleta, as the new Senate President Pro Tempore, succeeding current Pro Tem Mike McGuire. Limón is the first woman of color to hold the role, representing the Central Coast and rural parts of the state. Senators met over several hours and rounds of approval to make the decision, with some participating via Zoom. Limón's election marks a historic transition in California's Senate leadership ahead of her official start in early 2026.

stories.headline: Does Sacramento police chief's travel violate city rules?
stories.summary: Sacramento Police Chief Kathy Lester routinely flew first class or business class to attend 10 conferences during a one-year period ending in December 2024, raising questions about whether her travel violated city policy. Although the city's policy advises employees to travel economically, Lester reimbursed the city the difference between coach and first-class tickets. A Sacramento Bee review found her expenses included stays at top hotels and luxury sedans, which are more expensive options. Lester defended her travel, saying she did nothing wrong.

stories.headline: The ‘tremendous heartache’ of being Jewish on campus
stories.summary: Following protests and the rise of antisemitism, students and faculty at USC reflect on the challenges of being Jewish on campus. Some students report being targeted and subjected to offensive slogans while others discuss the broader implications of antisemitism in academic settings, particularly following heightened tensions after the Hamas-Israel conflict. The issue remains a significant concern for the campus community.

stories.headline: ‘Cali’ a 4-letter word in Vietnam
stories.summary: A new military museum in Vietnam features exhibits and artifacts relating to the U.S., but the term 'Cali,' referencing diaspora in the U.S., has become a slur amid rising nationalism. The museum and displays of controversial historical figures symbolizing communist victory spark mixed reactions, highlighting national sensitivities and the impact of history on current attitudes toward the Vietnamese-American community.

stories.headline: Sending Marines brings peril, questions
stories.summary: Military experts express concern about deploying troops trained for overseas combat to confront American protesters. With about 700 Marines from Twentynine Palms Air Ground Combat Center brought into Los Angeles at the request of federal officials, there are worries about the appropriateness and potential consequences of using military tactics in civilian urban protest settings. The deployment is viewed as an unusual and potentially risky experiment.

stories.headline: Troop arrival adds to local tension
stories.summary: U.S. Marines arrived in Los Angeles amid concerns over coordination between local police and federal forces during immigration-related protests. The Trump administration deployed 4,000 National Guard troops and 700 Marines to protect agents and federal buildings. Local law enforcement noted limited coordination with the federal troops, which resulted in tensions and crowd control challenges as some protesters turned violent.

stories.headline: Who is driving chaos in L.A.?
stories.summary: During protests in Los Angeles, violence flared with grim-faced police officers facing confrontations. While LAPD officers reported facing less lethal riot weapons, protesters hurled objects and some looted, leading to confrontations. Officials have struggled to quell unrest as demonstrators challenged law enforcement, raising questions about the true cause of chaos amid immigration sweeps by federal forces.

stories.headline: Search for Travis Decker intensifies after suspected sightings
stories.summary: The search for a former U.S. Army soldier accused of killing his three daughters is intensifying after multiple reported sightings. Authorities have been tracking trails and deploying search teams to the Enchantments area as they investigate reports of a lone hiker matching his description. Travis Decker is believed to be near Peshastin flying on Highway 97 and poses a significant manhunt challenge.

stories.headline: Mental health medications take long time to reach county jail, audit says
stories.summary: An audit revealed delays in King County jails providing psychiatric medications to inmates after booking, with some prisoners waiting days or weeks. The delays can compromise their health and the management of mental health conditions. Some inmates cannot access necessary medications promptly, making jail psychiatric staff's job more difficult.
